Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 01:24PM jhammel wrote: Elsewhere I have mentioned that my wife was discovered to have recurrence in the lung about a year ago, for which she had surgery. But she also had a very small tumor on the posterior section of her L5 vertebra (that's the last one down), and she had surgery to remove a small portion of the bone that had the tumor on it. Your post is timely since we also just received yesterday the news of her PET/CT scan done last week, 10 months after the spine surgery.  As in her first follow-up PET/CT from September, the radiologist noted some mild uptake at the surgical site, but did not indicate concern for malignancy, noting the uptake as likely 'chronic postoperative changes'.  I would have expected the report to indicate a greater level of concern if there was really any suspicion of cancer involved. When her original spine tumor was first detected by PET/CT early last year, an MRI was immediately recommended, but this time nothing - nor did her oncologist show any concern when we met with him yesterday.  My wife is due for a one-year follow-up spine MRI in April anyhow, so until then we're going to trust that the post-surgical activity is very likely the cause for the mild uptake.  If that MRI shows anything more serious, we'll deal with it then, but we have peace of mind now with our current status.  Other than that her PET/CT was clear, and she continues on with NED, which was actually her starting point since her surgeries last year completely removed the detectable recurrences of her cancer. In your case, I would get that MRI in a timely fashion if you think you need it for peace of mind, and until you get the results just try to remind yourself that no amount of worry is going to change anything.  If it's just post-surgical changes like everyone suspects, then it would be great to know that for sure.  On the off chance that it is cancer, it's better to know that for sure and so that you have the best chance of treating it appropriately.  The only thing you can really do helpful for yourself now is push for the MRI. Regarding other false positives, my wife had a tracheal lymph node with mild uptake on her original PET scan early last year - turned out to be nothing, and was probably due to the respiratory infection or bronchitis (still not sure what it was) that caused her to start getting things checked out in the first place.  Good thing she got sick though, since that's how we were able to discover her lung and spine tumors before they grew or spread further.  We thank our son's daycare for helping us give her a better chance at controlling this disease for a while.

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2011 02:44PM jhammel wrote: My wife was diagnosed last March 2010 with two recurrent tumors (original mastectomy and stage I diagnosis over 8 years earlier), one in the upper right lobe of the lung and a small one on the posterior of her spine at L5.  She had both removed surgically, then followed by 12 weekly taxol+herceptin.  She continues on tamoxifen and herceptin, as she is ER+/PR+/HER2+.  So far she is 15 months past the lung surgery (which was done second in May 2010) and still NED.  It was several weeks before she could be pain free without meds, but overall she tolerated the surgeries and the subsequent chemo very well, and we feel pretty good that surgery was the right choice for her.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2010 08:27PM - edited Oct 6, 2010 08:32PM by jhammel  I think my wife's situation is similar to your wife's.  My wife's scans during an investigational phase early this year (original mastectomy in 2002) showed evidence of a solitary 2cm nodule in her right lung and a small tumor (less than 1cm) on the posterior of her L5 lumbar vertabra.  She ended up having both removed surgically about a month apart, starting with the spine in April.  They had to proceed with the lung surgery since neither bronchoscopy nor pathology of the spine tumor was conclusive in determining whether it was breast cancer mets or primary lung cancer - turns out it was the breast cancer.  She recently completed a 12-week course of adjuvant Taxol+Herceptin, and will be continuing on Herceptin and hormone therapy from here out (she's triple positive).  So far so good - she had a PET scan just a couple weeks ago at the end of chemo and was NED, just as she was after the surgeries were completed.  I would have considered it surprisingly bad to have something new pop up that quickly.  Anyhow, her case is considered by her docs to be 'oligometastatic', and they too have indicated that her chance of long-term survival is better than the average stage IV, given the successful surgeries and subsequent NED status.  In her case, they base their optimism on her long interval to diagnosis of metastases (about 8 years), her limited degree of metastases, the fact that the ones they could see are now gone, and her triple positivity (giving her more treatment options as we move on).  Still, none of that gaurantees anything, and she could see this disease again at any time.  For now, we're just lucky she's NED and won't have to deal with chemo in the very immediate future.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2010 07:12PM jhammel wrote: My wife is through 10 of 12 weekly Taxol+Herceptin treatments.  This is her first systemic therapy.  She had her primary surgery in 2002, then was diagnosed with mets to lung and spine in March this year, but both were just small solitary tumors that were removable with surgery, and she started the T+H with no evidence of disease.  Your first day experience and hers sound identical.  She sleeps during treatment due to the benadryl, but is energetic later in the day.  She only felt the sleeplessness at night from the steroids the first few treatments.  Now she either doesn't feel it or uses a sleep aid and does fine.  She pretty much resumes her day as normal after leaving treatment.  As for side effects since then, she has lost most of her hair - it started coming out after about 2.5 weeks and we shaved it down just before the 5th treatment.  We have a toddler in daycare, and unfortunately my wife caught one of his viruses and has had difficulty shaking it.  The doctors gave her this week off from the Taxol while she fights off the virus since she may have an upper respiratory infection.  Anyhow, her cough and slight fever are because of the virus, but I'm sure being on chemo isn't doing her body any favors in fighting it.  Other than those things, my wife hasn't had any other issues - no extra fatigue or neuropathy.  I'm guessing overall her experience is probably on the better side, and I hope yours goes as well, but avoid those viruses floating lurking out there if you can.  Jeff

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2014 02:19PM - edited Aug 8, 2014 02:20PM by jhammel My wife is another "almost".  8 years after surgery for stage I, she had x-rays (which led to CT and PET scans) for a nagging respiratory infection, and doctors incidentally found a single 2cm nodule in her right lung, and also a very small nodule on the back of her lowest vertebrae on her spine.  Her lung biopsy was conclusive for cancer, but inconclusive for breast cancer metastasis or lung cancer.  She ended up having both the spine and lung tumors removed surgically just a few weeks apart.  Mets of breast cancer was confirmed for the lung tumor.  The spine tumor was inconclusive since it was mostly dead, but the presumption was also breast cancer mets.  She did chemo after that for just 3 months, and continues indefinitely with tamoxifen and Herceptin (she's triple positive).  So far she is 4.25 years out from those surgeries, all NED.

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2014 07:50PM jhammel wrote: It's been a while since I posted on here, but I wanted to quickly share my wife's situation. She was originally diagnosed Stage I following her breast surgery in 2002, and at that time declined any chemo or hormonal treatment (despite being triple positive).  Eight years later in 2010, after initially getting x-rayed due to a nagging respiratory infection, CT and PET confirmed a 2cm tumor on her lung, and the PET also revealed a small tumor on the back side of lowest vertebrae.  She had both the spine tumor and the lung tumor removed surgically, in that order, about a month apart.  The pathology of the spine tumor was unclear due to few living cells, while the pathology of the lung tumor confirmed breast cancer recurrence, and she did a 12-week round of Taxol and has been on tamoxifen and Herceptin ever since.  Now for the good news: almost 4 years out from the surgeries for those tumors, and still NED, and with no apparent significant side effects from her drugs.  Given the long time between her initial treatment in 2002 and the detection of the recurrences, their limited nature (despite no initial post-op treatment), and her NED state since, she so far fits what folks might mean when they say limited MBC with good outcome after local treatment..  I wish all cases were this favorable. Jeff

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2010 04:54PM jhammel wrote: my first post... My wife was recently diagnosed in March 2010 at age 46 with recurrence of her breast cancer, for which she had a complete mastectomy in Jan 2002 with no nodal involvement.  With respect to the recurrence, there were two detectable tumors upon a thorough imaging workup: one 2cm tumor in the upper lobe of her right lung, and a single tumor <1cm on the posterior of her lower spine (only impacting the bone, and in a very accessible position).  Cleveland Clinic surgeons completely removed both the spinal tumor (April, laminectomy) and the lung tumor (May, lobectomy).  Microscopic levels of involvement of two lymph nodes within the resected portion of the lung were also determined after surgery, presumably spread from the lung tumor (as opposed to indicating a pathway to the lung tumor) since no lymph nodes outside the lung were found to contain cancer on biopsy.  She was declared NED as of the completion of her surgeries, with a clean CT scan and pathologically negative surgical margins.  The lung tumor was triple positive, like her original cancer, but the spinal tumor was extensively necrotic (i.e. dead) and could not be accurately typed since it had too few living cancer cells left in it.  She is currently on a 12 week regimen of Taxol+Herceptin, to be followed later by more Herceptin + Tamoxifen.  She is tolerating the Taxol very well, with hair loss and mild fatigue being the only noticable symptoms through the first 6 weeks.  Her case is an example of aggressive local treatment of oligorecurrence (or oligometastasis), followed by appropriate systemic treatment for her cancer type.  We'll see what the future holds, and of course we hope she's among those that achieve "cure" (or at least holding the cancer at bay for many years) for oligorecurrence.  Jeff
